Graphical abstract The hydrotreating of waste cooking oil (WCO) to produce fuels not only solves waste problem but also recycles energy. CoMoS is regarded as an effective catalyst for the deoxygenation of triglyceride during the hydrotreating process; however, it is easy to deactivate. This article studied the deactivation mechanism of a supported CoMoS commercial catalyst during the hydrotreating of WCO. It was the first time to find triglyceride deoxygenation over different active sites during CoMoS catalyst deactivating process: saturated hydrocarbons were the primary products over MoS2 on the presulfided CoMoS catalyst, and unsaturated hydrocarbons were produced over MoO3 on the spent CoMoS catalyst as the transformation of the MoS2 into MoO3 occurred under high temperature operation. Three causes were observed for the deactivation of the studied catalyst: by-product water, loss of sulfur, and coke deposition. Low temperature operation at 275°C can control the deactivation of CoMoS catalyst due to coke deposition. In-situ drying and resulfiding the spent catalyst were proposed as methods to regenerate the spent catalyst. Keywords Deactivation mechanism Supported CoMoS catalyst Triglycerides hydrotreating Hydrodeoxygenation Waste cooking oil 1 Introduction Fossil fuels have been essential for transportation and chemical industries since industrialization. Continuous use of fossil fuels, however, has been consuming petroleum resources and rising environmental concerns. Therefore, many researchers are making efforts to develop renewable fuels to replace or supplement fossil fuels. In the current market, fatty acid methyl ester (FAME) biodiesel is one of the most popular renewable fuels [1,2]. Oxygen (8–15wt%) and carbon–carbon double bonds from triglycerides remain in FAME biodiesel [3,4]. The former leads to its polarity and low energy density (about 37.5MJ/kg) [5], and the latter makes it less stable, shortening its shelf life. Green diesel, produced from triglycerides by hydrotreating, contains rather low oxygenates (<1wt%) and presents high energy density (about 44.0MJ/kg) [5]. Another major advantage is that triglycerides can be easily integrated into the current hydrotreating infrastructure, and a deoxygenated and stable product that is similar in composition to petroleum-derived fuels can be produced [6–8]. Traditional sulfided CoMo or NiMo catalysts have been studied extensively for their potential use in the hydrotreating triglyceride process. A major problem is that these catalysts are readily deactivated during reaction [9]. Therefore, it has been debated whether sulfided hydrotreating catalysts can be economically employed for the deoxygenation of triglycerides. Loss of sulfur is one root cause of catalyst deactivation during the hydrotreating process [10–14]. Adding H2S or a sulfiding agent into the feed is a proposed solution to this problem − it would help to maintain the sulfided active sites and HDO activity of the catalysts during reaction. Krause observed that the presence of H2S (1000ppm) could effectively improve the conversions of methyl heptanoate from 82% to 96% on the NiMo catalyst and from 48% to 65% on the CoMo catalyst [10,11]. Laurent discovered that the rate constant of the conversion of di-ethyldecanedioate with the NiMo catalyst nearly doubled, from 5.2 to 9.3 *10−3, whereas with the CoMo catalyst increased by 30%, from 5.8 to 7.9 *10−3 when hydrogen sulfided was added from 0 to 0.2mol/L [12]. Kubicka reported that continually adding sulfur agent (0.5wt.% DMDS) ensured significantly slower catalyst deactivation during rapeseed oil hydrotreating process: the oxygen elimination increased from 75% to up to above 95% after 144h’ on stream [13]. However, Ferrari found that hydrogen sulfided did not affect the conversion of ethyldecanoate when its concentration increased from 10 to 150kPa under a total pressure of 7Mpa [14]. Researchers still have different views on reserving the sulfided active sites and HDO activity through adding a sulfiding agent in the feed. Even though it works, the excess sulfur from adding H2S or the sulfiding agent in the feed will remain in the gas products and removing it from the recycled hydrogen will be a problem. Another reason for the deactivation of these catalysts is that they produce water as by-product [10,12]. Krause observed that increasing water amounts to 1.9% decreased the conversions of methyl heptanoate by 15% over CoMo/Al2O3 and by 16% over NiMo/Al2O3 [10]. Laurent and Delmon discovered that the additional water with the initial concentration of 1.7–2.0mol/L (3–4%), caused approximately 20% decrease of the HDO of diethyldecanedioate using CoMo/Al2O3 catalyst [12]. Although researcher had same conclusion that the produced water decreased catalyst HDO activity during carboxylic ester hydrodeoxygenation process, it was necessary to investigate the deactivation mechanism, the reversibility of this deactivation, and further the regeneration of the deactivated catalyst. Other reasons for catalyst deactivation were also reported in the literature − coke formation was significant among them [15]. Badawi et al. [16] found that the extent of water poisoning to Co-promoted MoS2 was rather lower in extent and has full reversibility, which is attributed to Co atoms because it prevented the exchanges of sulfur by oxygen. Guichard et al. [17] concluded that coke (reversible) particularly influenced the CoMo active phase, but segregation (irreversible) did to the ‘NiMoS’ mixed phase even though the residence time in the pilot plant was considerably short. Therefore, a CoMoS supported hydrotreating catalyst was selected in the current study. According to the summary above, the deactivation of CoMoS supported catalyst has presented a challenge to process design and operation; therefore, a complete understanding of catalyst deactivation is necessary to both develop new catalysts and improve the lifetime of the existing catalyst [18–20]. Compared to petroleum hydrotreating (which removes sulfur and nitrogen), the purpose of triglyceride hydrotreating is to remove oxygen. Therefore, it is vital to understand how oxygenates influence catalyst activity during triglyceride upgrading using sulfided hydrotreating catalysts. At the moment, the deactivation mechanisms of sulfided catalysts during the hydrotreating process have been comprehensively studied for model oils but rarely for real triglyceride based bio-oils. Using a real triglyceride based biofuel, waste cooking oil, as feed to produce green diesel, will not only solve waste problem but also recycle energy. In this work, the deactivation of the supported CoMoS commercial catalyst during the hydrotreating of waste cooking oil was studied. Two areas of deactivation are proposed. The first one consists of the effects occurring due to oxygenates, such as by-product water, the oxygenated compounds in the liquid products, and the oxide active components on the catalysts. The second consists of more traditional deactivation causes, such as the appearance of coke deposition. In situ drying of the catalyst was carried out to investigate the magnitude of water formation effects on deactivation as well. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst activity evaluation WCO was offered by McCain Foods Limited. WCO with a concentration of 10wt% in dodecane was used as feed. Dodecane was purchased from Fischer Scientific and used as received. The properties and compositions of WCO were shown in Supplemental File 1 (SF 1) and the previous publication [21]. The catalyst selected in the current study is a commercial supported hydrotreating catalyst (Liaoning Haitai Sci-TechDevelopment Co., Ltd., China), whose active components are Co and Mo, and the support consists of alumina, silica, and titania. The element compositions of the catalyst are shown in Table 2. Prior to the experiment, the catalyst underwent in-situ drying, presulfiding, conditioning, and stabilization. Sulfur-donating agent was not added in the feed during all process only except for the presulfiding and conditioning process. Samples were taken at the 77th, 107th, 138th, 177th, and 213th hours on steam. The five samples were named Ri where i is from 1 to 5. The feed was hydrotreated in an BTRS-JR-PC fixed bed microreactor (Parker Autoclave Engineers, USA) over a commercial CoMo hydrotreating catalyst at 275°C and 7.58MPa for 220h. Liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV) was set at 3h−1 and the volume ratio of H2 to oil at 50ml/ml. All selected conditions are based on our previous testing [22]. The Catalyst setup, pretreatment, and reaction system are described in SF 2. 2.2 Catalyst characterization All the spent catalyst characterized in this work was the catalyst spent for 222h on the stream. The presulfided catalyst refers to the catalyst that was not done for conditioning and stabilization. NH3-TPD used for testing the strength and number of active sites on the surface of catalysts was tested by a Quantachrome Autosorb 1-C (Quantachrome Instruments, USA) and a Residue Gas Analyzer (RGA-200, Stanford Research Systems Inc., USA). The type and strength of acids on catalyst surface was tested by Pyridine-FTIR (Nicolet FTIR-6700, Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., USA). Catalyst samples were degassed at 400°C in a Helium flow for 1h. The system was evacuated to 100 micron by a high vacuum pump at 100°C before pyridine was introduced for adsorption. Infrared spectra were recorded at temperatures of 100, 150, 250, and 350°C. The scanning was performed under the following conditions: a KBr pellet as background, 32s of scanning, a resolution of 4cm−1, and a scanning range of 4000–400cm−1. Data obtained from the spectrometer was analyzed by Omnic 8 software. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) and temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) were respectively used to investigate the amount and strength of the hydrogenation active sites on catalyst, and the type and amount of coke on spent catalyst by a Quantachrome Autosorb 1-C and a RGA-200. The surface area, pore volume, and pore size distribution of both presulfided and spent catalysts were measured at 77K on an Autosorb 1-C. The testing parameters and the calculation methods are the same to the previous publication [15]. TEM and Energy dispersive x-ray (EDX) spectroscopy were used to determine and compare the morphology of active metals between the presulfided and the spent catalysts. A JEOL 2011 Scanning Transmission Electron Microscope (JEOL Ltd., Japan) with the EDX (Genesis 4000 spectrometer) system was applied in the current study. The average slab length and the average number of layers were calculated by the same methods presented in a previous publication [23]. The catalyst samples were dried at 100°C with a flowing nitrogen before X-ray photo electron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis. The measurements were performed on Leybold MAX-200 Spectrometer (Leybold, Germany). Al K-alpha was used as source. The analysis area was 4 * 7mm2. For the survey scans, the pass energy was 192eV and the collected binding energy ranged from 1000eV to 0. For the narrow scan measurement of Mo 3d, the pass-energy was 48eV and the collected binding energy ranged from 240 to 224eV. A Renishaw inVia Raman microscope (Renishaw, UK), with a mid-range wavelength, a He–Ne gas mixture at 633nm, was used to do the Raman spectroscopy testing. Thermal properties of the presulfided and spent catalysts were tested with 10% oxygen in helium by thermal gravimetric analyzer (TGA, TA instrument, USA) and pressure differential scanning calorimeter (DSC, Instrument Specialists Incorporated, USA), respectively. The elemental compositions of the catalyst were tested by a JEOL JXA-733 Electron Probe Micro-analyser (JEOL Ltd., Japan) running with automation software (Geller Microanalytical automation control (dSspec, dQant32, dPict32)), and equipped with both wavelength dispersive spectrometers and energy dispersive spectrometers. Total sulfur content was determined by an Antek Nitrogen/Sulfur Analyzer (NS-9000, Antek Instrument Inc., USA). Carbon contents for coke deposition testing were tested by CHN-932 (LECO Corporation, USA) following ASTM D 5291. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was collected in the range of 5–75°, 2θ with a step of 0.02° and 1.0s on a Bruker D8 Advance spectrometer (Bruker Corporation, Germany) at an operating current of 40kV and 30mA. 2.3 Product analysis The water content and the total acid number (TAN) were determined according to ASTM D 4377 and ASTM D 664, respectively, using a 701 KF Titrano (Metrohm AG, Switzerland) and a ZD-2 potentiometric titrator (Shanghai Ai Yi Qi Shi Ye Co. Ltd., China). A Nicolet FTIR-6700 was used to analyze functional groups in the feed and oil products. H NMR analyses were conducted on a Varian UNITY INOVA 300MHz spectrometer (Agilent Technologies, Inc., USA) to determine the presence and relative intensity of hydrogen containing functional groups. The compositions of feed and liquid products were determined by a gas chromatograph (SHIMADZU GC-17A), which was equipped with an Agilent HP-5MS column, coupled with a mass spectrometer (SHIMADZU MS-QP5000) (GC/MS, Shimadzu Scientific Instruments, Japan). The contents of oxygenates were calculated from GC/MS results by the peak area and response factors [24]. The contents of hydrocarbons were determined by external standard method using a Varian 450 gas chromatograph (Agilent Technologies, In., USA) with an FID, equipped with an Agilent J&WVF–1ms column. 3 Results 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Active sites 3.1.1.1 Acidic sites The number and strength of acidic sites on a catalyst can be representative of cracking capability, which was tested by NH3-TPD. It was expected that acidity should have been decreased in the spent catalyst because of coke deposition, but this was not found to be the case. Fig. 1 shows that the strength of acids on the spent catalyst was higher than that on the presulfided catalyst. These results indicate that significant changes happened on the surface of the catalyst during reaction and altered the amount and strength of the acidic sites. As shown in SF 3, a slight decrease in the total amount of acidity on catalyst surface, from 2.5 to 2.3mmol/g, occurred after 222h’ operation. The types and strength of acidic sites on catalysts tested by Pyridine-FTIR are shown in Fig. 2 . The characteristic bands at 1450cm−1 and 1550cm−1 were assigned to Lewis acid sites and Bronsted acid sites, respectively. As shown in Fig. 2, some Bronsted acids were produced on the surface of spent catalyst due to the appearance of the peak at 1541cm−1. Even though the acids on the Al2O3 and TiO2 are typically Lewis acid only, strong acidic sites were generated when MoO3 was deposited on alumina and silica, and strong Bronsted acids were produced when MoO3 was loaded on titania, which is supported by other researchers [25–27]. Comparing Fig. 2 (a) to (b), one can see that the acid specific peaks disappeared at 250°C for the presulfided catalyst where the acid specific peaks for the spent catalysts can be observed until 350°C. Thus, the acid strength of the spent catalyst was slightly enhanced. 3.1.1.2 Active sites The amount of consumed H2 and released H2S are the indicators of the amount of hydrogenation and HDO active sites that existed on the catalysts, which is tested by TPR, as shown in Fig. 3 . To address the released/consumed gases amount and peak areas, we did calibration curves and calculated response amount of the gases, which were shown in SF 3. According to Fig. 3, there was a significant difference in the hydrogen consumption observed between the presulfided catalyst and the spent catalyst. When the catalyst’s testing temperature was lower than 733–K (460°C), the total amount of hydrogenation active sites dramatically decreased from 2.1 to 0.1mmol/g (shown in SF 3). There was hydrogen released from spent catalyst when the testing temperature was higher than 460°C. This occurred because the precursor to the coke produced was decomposed and hydrogen was consequently released. The effectiveness of hydrogenation active sites also decreased significantly during the reaction. As shown in Fig. 3, there was a small H2S peak in the TPR results of the presulfided catalyst, but a significantly smaller H2S peak in the TPR result of spent catalyst, which shows that the HDO capability of the catalyst obviously decreased. Overall, the hydrogenation and HDO activities of the presulfided catalyst were much higher than those of the spent catalyst. 3.1.2 Morphology and chemical state of Mo TEM and EDX were used to determine and compare the morphologies of the presulfided catalyst and the spent catalyst. This helped to determine whether any active metals were lost or aggregated during the hydrotreating process. Representative TEM micrographs and basic properties of the presulfided and spent catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 and Table 1 , respectively. After undergoing hydrotreating, the layers of MoS2 decreased significantly, so did the length of crystalline as well (from 5.8 to 5.1nm). The stacks in the presulfided catalyst consisted of an average of 2.3 layers, whereas most of stacks in the spent catalyst had only one layer left (average 1.5 of layers). When TiO2 was used as support, multi-layered MoS2 clusters (Co-Mo–S (II)) possessed higher activities than single-layered MoS2 clusters (Co–Mo–S (I)) [29]. When Al2O3 was used as support, an increase in the number of stacking layers weakened the polarization of the aluminum ions on the alumina surface and improved the ability of cobalt on molybdenum to form CoMoS active phases [30]. The TPR results show that there was no H2S released from the use of the spent catalysts, which supports the conclusion that the amount of active MoS2 decreased during reaction. This conclusion can also be supported by the fact that the fraction of edge metal atoms increased due to the loss of sulfur. The XPS results of these two catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 and Table 2 . There is a ‘triplet' because of the overlapping of two doublets. It was found that the high-resolution XPS spectra of Mo (Fig. 5) showed a good consistency of the signal for Mo 3d fitting into two doublets. Mo (IV) 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 are responsible for the doublet at 229.3 and 233.8eV, respectively. Mo (VI) 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 are responsible for the doublet at 232.6eV and 236.1eV, respectively [31,32]. As shown in Fig. 5, the doublets of Mo 3d5/2,3/2 centered at 236.1 and 232.6eV are enhanced after the catalyst are spent for 222h on the stream. It indicates that the spent catalyst has more Mo (VI) than the presulfided catalyst. The intensity of the peak at 229.3eV is significantly reduced when compared the spent catalyst to the presulfided catalyst. This evidenced that the catalyst lost Mo (IV) during hydrotreating process. These results are also in accordance with the Py-FTIR testing results: some medium strong Bronsted acids were produced on the surface of spent catalyst due to MoO3 was deposited on alumina, silica, and titania. Raman spectroscopy was used to confirm the existence of MoO3 on spent catalyst. The results are shown in SF 4. Unfortunately, based on literature [33], MoO3 in the catalyst seems to be amorphous because except for the graphite signals shown in the spent catalyst Raman spectrum, there is no obvious signal in Raman spectra for the fresh oxide, the presulfided, and the spent catalyst testing results. Contrary to the previous publication [19], no metal aggregation was found. As shown in Table 1 and Fig. 4, the phenomenon maybe caused by the loss of peripheral sulfurs in CoMoS crystallites and the mixture of support (with not only alumina, but also silica and titania), which diminishes the aggregation. 3.1.3 Elemental compositions Table 3 shows the elemental compositions of the presulfided and spent catalysts. As can be seen from Table 3, the differences between the elemental compositions of the presulfided and the spent catalyst (measured by the relative content of the element’s atomic ratio to Al) were not more than 0.02, except for those of sulfur and carbon. This indicates that, besides sulfur and carbon, none of the compositional elements in the catalysts decreased during the hydrotreating process. Only the ratio of sulfur content decreased by 0.10, which reveals that sulfur was lost during the reaction. This conclusion has been confirmed by the NS-9000 results. As shown in Table 3, after 222h on stream, virtually no leaching of metals was observed. This may be because the low blend ratio of WCO in the feed: only 10wt% triglyceride in dodecane. Based on the variation of active sites, morphology and chemical state of Mo, and elemental compositions, the active components of the sulfided catalyst (MoS2) have been converted into metal oxides during the HDO process, which was attributed to the existence of oxygenates in the feed [34,35]. It is also noted that 21.5% carbon was produced after 222h of reaction, indicating severe carbon deposition and coke formation. 3.1.4 Coke deposition Table 1 and SF 5 show the variations in physical properties of the catalyst after 222h’ reaction. The surface area, pore volume, and average pore size obviously decreased after the reaction. Coke formation on the surface of the catalyst was responsible for this decrease. In the research presented in this work, coke burning was conducted. SF 6 and Fig. 6 show the amount of consumed or released gases and the existence of peaks, which indicate that different kinds of coke were deposited on the spent catalyst. Unwashed oil product and H2O were present in the first burning zone 393–673 K (120–400°C). The precursors to coke were aromatics with less than three rings − this was known because the ratio of H/C of 3-ring aromatics was 0.7. These were detected in the second burning zone 673–773 K (400–500°C), which corresponded with the oxycarbide and soft coke [20]. Poly-aromatics that had more than three rings were found in the third burning zone (at temperature higher than 773K (500°C)), which corresponded with the graphitic coke deposited in acidic sites [36]. As shown in Fig. 6, the SO2 amount was an exception to the other values. The release of SO2 was distributed in the first and second burning zones rather than the second and third zones. The reason for this is that the driving force of converting MoS2 and Co9S8 into metal oxide and SO2 was higher than that of converting carbon into CO2 and CO [37]. The confirmation information of the replacement of sulfur with oxygen in CoMoS spent catalyst due to the negligible SO2 release peak in TPO results shown in Fig. 6. To confirm the effect of coke deposition on the decrease of catalyst surface area, the BET test of the regenerated-spent by burnt and the fresh oxide catalyst were conducted. The surface area of the regenerated-spent catalyst and the fresh oxide catalyst are 175.5 and 176.9m2/g, respectively. Compared these two results, the coke deposition is proven to be one of the main deactivated reason for the studied catalyst and the pore structure was changed to a very small extent because the surface areas are similar between the fresh oxide and regenerated-spent catalysts. Also, there is no sintering observed on spent catalyst. Beside, O2-TGA and DSC of the presulfided and spent catalysts were conducted. The results are shown in Figs. 7 and 8 . As can be seen in these two figures, (I) is the absorbed water zone. (II) is the transformation of MoS2 to MoOx zone which has a lower heat flow peak at temperature around 300°C in the presulfided catalyst DSC result. The results are in accordance with XPS, NH3-TPD, and Py-FTIR results: MoO3 was produced from MoS2 through being oxidized by oxygenates. (III) is the coke deposition burning zone. The results are in accordance with the carbon element content, BET, and TPO results: coke deposition was one of the main deactivated reasons, and the coke deposition was burnt at 550°C. 3.1.5 Crystal structures The XRD results (in Fig. 9 ) show that TiO2 (PDF 21-1272) and γ-Al2O3 (PDF 46-1131) were present in all of the three tested samples. TiO2 (PDF 21-1272) had a better crystallinity over γ-Al2O3 (PDF 46-1131) [30] − this was shown by TiO2’s higher intensity and sharper diffraction peak. The broad peak around 20° was from SiO2. No obvious peak of MoO3 or CoO was observed in the XRD patterns of the un-sulfided oxide catalyst, but a small peak attributing to β-CoMoO4 (PDF 21-868) was found at 26.5°, which is in accordance with the Raman spectroscopy testing results. The reason is that the MoO3 in this catalyst was amorphous. These peaks disappeared after the catalyst was sulfided, when the characteristic peaks of MoS2 appeared. XRD could determine whether the sintering of the active metals or catalyst support occurred during hydrotreating, but CoMoS catalysts needed to be processed for a long time at more severe conditions to exhibit extensive MoS2 sintering, segregated Co sulfided phase formation, or support sintering [38]. The changes in Mo and Co dispersion that occurred between the presulfided and spent catalysts were confined to a rather limited range, which was reflected in the XRD patterns [39]. Laurent and Delmon found that the result of partial gamma-alumina support crystallisation turned into a hydrated boehmite phase because of the existence of large amounts of water (the partial pressure of water was 2.5MPa under a total pressure of 7MPa) [40]. Boehmite specific peaks were not detected in the XRD results of the spent catalyst (Fig. 9). It can therefore be concluded that, based on XRD results, there were no obvious sintering phenomena for the catalyst support or active metals of the sulfided CoMo catalyst after 222h’ triglyceride hydrotreating reaction, which is in accordance with the BET testing results of the regenerated-spent and the fresh oxide catalysts. 3.2 Variation of products with time-on-stream (TOS) 3.2.1 Products’ properties No water was detected in all samples. Table 4 indicates the results of the acidity tests. The TAN results show that some samples were significantly more acidic than the feed, even though the former had been hydrotreated. This acidity increase was due to the appearance of some intermediates in those samples, which included alcohols and aldehydes. These intermediates were more acidic than the ester functional groups in the feed triglycerides. During the process of R1 to R5, a temperature of 365°C was used twice to make clear the effects of high temperatures on catalyst activities, between R1 and R2, and between R2 and R3, respectively. As shown in Table 4, there were no big differences in TAN for the first high temperature operation, whereas a large TAN variation ranging from 0.5 to 7.2mg KOH/g was observed for the second high temperature operation. When the temperature was lowered back to 275°C, the TAN remained as high as 5.7mg KOH/g. This result reveals a decrease in deoxygenation activity due to high temperature operation; high temperature was found to be a cause of catalyst deactivation. 3.2.2 Products’ structure FTIR and H NMR analyses are shown in Fig. 10 . The corresponding of related IR wavenumbers to functional groups is listed in SF 7. Throughout all the FTIR results, spectra consistently show a strong presence of alkane groups in the wavenumber ranges of 3000–2850cm−1 and 1500–1400cm−1. However, as shown in Fig. 10 (a), the samples from R3 to R5 exhibit peaks at around 3200cm−1 and in the range of 1750–1500cm−1. These peaks are the evidence of the existence of oxygenated compounds. The H NMR results show the evidence of a higher concentration of primary hydrogen (peaks ranged of 0–1.2ppm), lower amounts of oxygen containing functional groups (peaks ranged of 2–4.4ppm and around 10ppm), and lower amounts of carbon–carbon double bonds (peaks ranged of 1.9-2.1ppm and 5.2-5.5ppm) in the products than in the WCO (Fig. 10 (b)). Carbon-carbon double bonds existed in the products of R2 to R5, and a certain amount of oxygenates existed in R3 to R5 as well. 3.3 Variation of catalyst activities After triglyceride hydrotreating, the products should ideally be 100% paraffinic − all oxygen should be removed and all carbon–carbon double bonds should be saturated. Three categories of reaction thereby were discussed: hydrogenation, deoxygenation, and cracking reactions. 3.3.1 Hydrogenation activity Fig. 11 shows the variation of oxygenate, alkane, and alkene selectivity observed in the reaction products against TOS. When considering the usability of fuels, a high content of carbon–carbon double bonds is unfavorable because their presence makes the fuel unstable. It can be observed that the content of unsaturated hydrocarbons gradually increased with the increasing of TOS, which indicates that the hydrogenation activity decreased. During the first 100h of operation, all double bonds could be saturated. A temperature of 365°C was introduced to test the effects of high temperature on the catalyst activities. This condition started at about the 100th hour of TOS and remained for 4h; the temperature was then lowered back to 275°C. The alkene content in the hydrotreated oil rose from 0 to 8.9% after the temperature of 365°C was employed. And then the high temperature was tested again to confirm its influence. It is worth mentioning that the second high temperature operation did not affect the hydrogenation activity too much and the final liquid product contained 10.6% of alkenes. The hydrogenation capability of the catalyst was significantly reduced because of the severely high temperature; therefore, it can be concluded that high temperature had a remarkable impact on catalyst hydrogenation activity. Moreover, the hydrogenation activity was stable during the TOS range of 138.5–213h. The alkenes were present for two reasons: cracking reactions (resulting in alkenes lighter than C15) and insufficient hydrogenation capability of HDO process after alcohol dehydration (resulting in alkenes ranging from C15 to C18); and these are shown in Fig. 12 . Regardless of the reason for the decrease in catalyst hydrogenation activity, alkene content can be used to determine variations in catalyst hydrogenation capability. As shown in Fig. 12, the main reason for the decrease in hydrogenation capability was the insufficient hydrogenation that occurred after the dehydration of alcohols. Teerawit proposed that MoO3 was an effective catalyst for the deoxygenation of bio-oil into unsaturated hydrocarbons through HDO pathways [20,41]. The results shown in Fig. 11 and Fig. 12 have confirmed the above discussion − part of MoS2 has been converted into MoO3. 3.3.2 Deoxygenation activity The hydrogenation of unsaturated triglycerides into saturated occurred firstly during the triglyceride hydrotreating process. Then the saturated triglycerides were broken down into diglyceride, monoglyceride, and fatty acid intermediates. These intermediates could then undergo two further reaction pathways: HDO and HDC. In the HDO pathway, fatty acids reacted with hydrogen, forming aldehydes and water. These aldehydes could then react with hydrogen to produce alcohols, and the alcohols could undergo subsequent dehydration, producing hydrocarbons and water. The HDC pathway might occur through two distinct routes: cracking to produce alkenes, water, and carbon monoxide; and removing CO2 to produce alkanes. Therefore, one carbon atom was removed from HDC and no carbon atom was removed from HDO. Since WCO was mainly composed of C18 fatty acids (91%), the occurrences of the two reaction pathways were easily deduced by comparing C18 and C17 fractions of the final product. Fig. 13 shows the C18 and C17 fractions, and the C18 to C17 ratios. For all samples, C18 paraffins were dominant over C17 paraffins, which suggests that HDO was generally more prevalent over HDC reactions. As the TOS increased, the fraction of C18 and the ratio of C18 to C17 decreased, especially after the temperature was increased to 365°C for the second time, from 107 to 138.5h. However, the fraction of C17 barely changed. Therefore, it can be concluded that the second 365°C operation only reduced HDO ability, but did not affect the HDC ability. It should be noted that the first 365°C operation did not influence the HDO capability. The deoxygenation activities were stable within the range of 138.5–213h. Fig. 14 shows that 22.5-25.0% oxygenated compounds that were detected in the liquid products were alcohols; there were also less than 2.5% of aldehydes, esters, and ethers. The ester compound, stearic acid propyl ester, was only found in R5 sample. The only aldehyde present was octadecanal, which presented itself in samples R3 to R5 in concentrations of 1.3-1.7wt%. The alcohols existing in the products were hexadecanol and octadecanol, which were present in concentrations of 0.8-0.9% and 21.5-23.6%, respectively. In particular, octadecanol was the primary oxygenate contained in liquid products, especially for experiments R3-R5. Even though the TAN are as high as 7mg KOH per gram sample in Table 4, neither hydroxyl nor carbonyl groups were detected by FTIR and HNMR. No organic acids were identified by GC/MS. The appearance of alcohols and hexadecanal helped to explain the TAN results because they react with the KOH titration solution. The presence of high concentration C18 and C16 alcohols confirmed that the number of active sites for the dehydration of alcohols to hydrocarbons obviously decreased. 3.3.3 Cracking activity As shown in Fig. 15 , C15 to C18 hydrocarbons had the highest concentrations among contained compounds in all products. Based on the compositions of feed oil, these results are expected. The cracking activity was determined by the content of C15− hydrocarbons in the products. The desired products of triglyceride hydrotreating were products in the diesel fraction, so cracking reactions were undesirable. During hydrotreating, there was no significant difference in cracking or polymerization capabilities (Fig. 15). Based on the discussion above, two obvious effects of deactivation by high temperature operation were observed: the rapid deactivation of hydrogenation activity after a TOS of 100h and the subsequent deactivation of HDO activity after a TOS of around 130h. 4 Discussion During the hytrotreating of triglycerides using supported CoMo sulfided catalyst, two categories of catalyst deactivation mechanisms are proposed in this work. The first category involves all sources of deactivation caused by oxygenates. These are not found in petroleum hydrotreating processes because of the low oxygen content in petroleum feed. Oxygenates include by-product water, oxygenated compounds in the liquid phase, and remaining metal oxide components on the catalyst produced by metal sulfided that was exchanged by oxygenates in the feed/products. The second category encompasses the existence of both coking (coke covers the active sites on the catalyst’s surface) and sintering (the crystal undergoes phase change). These are the same factors that cause catalyst deactivation in petroleum hydrotreating. 4.1 Oxygenate deactivation 4.1.1 Exchange of MoS2 into MoO3 The HDO reaction mechanism seems to be dominant in the experiments conducted in this work. This reaction is the same as the classical mechanism involving sulfur vacancies in the HDS process [42–46]. According to the HDS theory proposed by Qian [43], the HDO reaction mechanism and catalyst deactivation mechanism are proposed in Scheme 1 : (I) oxygen in the reactants is transferred to the catalyst, sulfur on the catalyst active site is released in the form of H2S, and sulfur is replaced by oxygen during the HDO process. Therefore, one of the reasons for catalyst deactivation during triglyceride hydrotreating was the exchange of oxygen (from oxygenates) with sulfur in the active phases of the catalysts [47]. Meanwhile, the oxide phase could be resulfided into sulfided phase by H2S, as shown in Scheme 1 (II). Table 5 lists thermodynamic data for possible reactions of the sulfur/oxygen exchange in MoS2. Reactions are possibly favorable when ΔGf<50kJ/mol [48]. The thermodynamic data clearly indicates that there was a tendency for some MoS2-like structures to be converted into MoO3/MoO2. This might have occurred due to some of the Mo undergoing oxidation from Mo4+ to Mo6+ at high temperatures and with the presence of oxygen containing compounds. In the experiments, insufficient quantities of sulfur were used to maintain the catalyst in its sulfided form. Other authors discovered the same MoS2 conversions when investigating coal-derived feed hydroprocessing [34,47]. Ferrari [14] reported that the increase of sulfur amount restored some activity to the catalyst; however, the corrosion caused by the excess H2S and the removal of it will cause further problems. The main active phase of the catalyst before being sulfided was MoO3, so resulfiding the catalyst could recover the decrease in catalytic activity caused by the loss of sulfur. The sample R5 was collected at 213h time-on-stream when the catalyst was very close to the spent catalyst that was characterized in this work. The R5 sample contains neither fatty acids or triglyceride. Fatty acid and triglyceride had been completely converted to alcohols, aldehydes, esters, and ethers, which resulted in high oxygen contents in the sample. It suggested that the spent catalyst still had deoxygenation activity. MoO2 is not active for hydrodeoxygenation. Most of MoS2 has been lost. Therefore, we were anticipated the existing state of most of Mo was in the state of MoO3. Prasomsri et al. supported MoO3 is an effective hydrodeoxygenation catalyst [20,41]. Besides, as discussed in Table 5, there exists the possibility of the reaction to produced MoO3. Evidenced by catalyst activity and characterization testing results, triglycerides were deoxygenated into saturated hydrocarbons (R1 with TOS at the 77th hour) through HDO pathway over supported CoMoS catalyst with only Lewis acids. However, high temperature operation promoted the transformation of the MoS2 into MoO3, and strong Bronsted acids were produced when MoO3 was deposited on the catalyst support. Therefore, the first high temperature operation (TOS at the 100th hour) made part of MoS2 transform into MoO3 and Bronsted acids were produced at the same time. Although the deoxygenation followed the same reaction pathway, HDO, unsaturated hydrocarbons were produced during triglyceride hydrotreating over MoO3 catalyst. Therefore, a content of 9% alkenes was produced when the TOS was at the 100th hour. With the existence of Bronsted acids on catalyst, high temperature operation significantly enhanced the coke deposition produced from unsaturated hydrocarbons. Thus, the second high temperature operation of TOS at the 134th hour severely promoted the formation of coke, which occupied the active sites on catalyst surface and resulted in the reduction of deoxygenation activity from TOS at 138th hour. Therefore, before the first high temperature operation, the deoxygenation of triglycerides followed the CoMoS HDO reaction pathway with the production of alkanes, whereas a part of it followed the MoO3 HDO reaction pathway after the first high temperature operation with the production of alkenes. Even though the deoxygenation activity did not change after the first high temperature was introduced, the reaction pathway and the hydrogenation activity did. Samples were taken at the 77th, 107th, 138th, 177th, and 213th hour. The first and the second high temperature, at 365°C, were introduced when the TOS were at 104th and 134th hour, respectively. To convincingly show the correlation between the different reactivity and specific active sites, the catalysts before and after each high temperature treatment were tested by TPR, XPS, and elemental compositions were also tested in order to evaluate the change in compositions and electronic states. The results are shown in Table 6 . As can be seen in Table 6, after high temperature treatment, the released H2S and the sulfur content apparently declined, and meanwhile the relative content of Mo6+ increased and that of Mo4+ decreased, which indicates that high temperature treatment significantly improved the converting of MoS2 to MoO3 under the testing conditions. Furthermore, the coke deposition was severely enhanced by the second high temperature treatment. All the above results are in accordance with the reactivity testing results and confirm the change in catalyst surface during high temperature treatment. To examine the regenerability of sulphur loss, the spent catalyst was resulfided. The sulphur content increased from 5.9% to 8.8%, which indicates that the loss of sulphur was partially recovered by resulfiding the spent catalyst. 4.1.2 Water effect Water was a by-product of the triglyceride hydrotreating process. To examine the effects of moisture during experimentation, catalyst was in-situ dried with the flowing of nitrogen at the 215th hour of TOS. As shown in Table 7 , 12.3% of hydrogenation and 18.3% deoxygenation activities could be recovered after the spent catalyst was dried. The HDO activity was also recovered by 11.7%, but there was no significant change in HDC activity − these changes correlated well with the activity losses exhibited due to TOS. On stream, the HDO capability decreased much more than the non-decreasing HDC capability (shown in Fig. 13). This shows that moisture was a key factor in catalyst deactivation and by-product water greatly hindered hydrogenation and HDO. Yoshimura [47] and Lavopa [50] also arrived at the same conclusion. There were no changes in cracking and polymerization capabilities that occurred due to water. It is possibly attributed to the fact that the by-product, water, occupied the hydrogeneation and HDO active sites. Badawi et al. [16] studied how water projected its impact on the stability of Mo and CoMo sulfided catalysts when it took part in the hydrodeoxygenation of phenolic compounds. For non-promoted MoS2 catalysts, they found that because of the presence of water, an exchange occurred to edge sulfur atoms on an important fraction of, which in turn alerted the nature of the active sites, but as metioned above, the extent of water poisoning, reversible and much lower, had small impact on Co-promoted catalyst, which is due to Co atoms preventting sulfur–oxygen from exchanges. This is not agreeable with our finding that Co-promoted catalyst was observed a great extent of oxygen replacement. One possible reason is that the molarity ratio of Co to Mo of our catalyst, 0.19 is much lower than that of Badawi’s catalyst, which is 0.74. The weak peak of Co was quite low in the presulfided catalyst XPS result. As a result, CoMoS active phase in the studied catalyst is much less than those in Badawi’s catalyst; therefore, the main active phase still are the MoS2 in our catalyst, whereas those are CoMoS in Badawi’s. TGA/MS testing was conducted to examine if the water is fully removed by in situ drying. The results were shown in Fig. 16 . As can be seen in Fig. 16, the water release peak was up over 750K; therefore, water cannot be fully removed by in situ drying. To examine the effects of water on reactivity during hydrotreating process, water was added in the feed for the second time, the results were shown in Table 8 . As can be seen in Table 8, after water being added in the feed, the dehydrogenation capability was improved by the Bronsted acids, which was produced by MoO3 loaded on catalyst support through the exchange of MoS2 to MoO3 that was enhanced by water. To examine the effect of adding water on coke deposition, with 10wt% and without water under a temperature of 380°C to accelerate the coke deposition, two tests were conducted. The carbon contents were 10.2% and 5.4% for without and with adding water respectively. Therefore, adding water in the feed significantly reduced the coke deposition, which is one of the reasons that water is frequently used as carrier gas in fluid catalytic cracking unit. 4.2 General deactivation causes 4.2.1 Coke deposition The physical contact of coke or its precursor with the catalyst surface resulted in the blocking of active sites and the plugging of pores [34]. The chemisorption of unsaturated hydrotreating products might have increased the chance for condensation to form coke by sequential dehydrogenation reactions. The formation starts from alkenes, alkene cyclization to form substituted cycloalkanes, the dehydrogenation of cycloalkanes into cycloalkenes, the dehydrogenation of cycloalkenes into aromatics, and aromatics transforming into poly-aromatics. The formation of coke was facilitated on Bronsted acids rather than on Lewis acids [51,52] via carbonium ion intermediates on Bronsted acidic sites [53] − this was in accordance with the Pyridine-FTIR results shown in 3.1.1.1. For confirming the coke deposition is one of the main deactivation reasons, the spent catalyst was burnt (10°C/min to 650°C for an hour according to TPO results), resulfided, and tested the reactivity testing. The fresh catalyst underwent the same treatment and reactivity testing for comparing the burning effects because sintering was found occurring during hydrotreating catalyst regeneration by burning out the coke. The produced liquid product compositions were shown in Table 9 . As can be seen in Table 9, compared to the spent catalyst liquid products, the deoxygenation capability of burnt spent catalyst was significantly improved, but the hydrogenation capability decreased, which may cause by active metal sintering that happened during being burnt. Compared to presulfided catalyst, both the deoxygenation and the hydrogenation capabilities decreased. Compared to burnt fresh catalyst, both the deoxygenation and the hydrogenation reaction capabilities were lower, which indicates that the reactivity was not fully recovered from burning out the coke deposition. 4.2.2 Sintering Sintering usually refers to the activity loss caused by crystal growth or active metal migration/aggregation change on a catalyst. Judging from XRD, and TEM results, sintering was not obviously observed in the studied catalyst during the hydrotreating process. 5 Conclusions In this work, the deactivation of the supported CoMoS commercial catalyst during the hydrotreating of WCO was studied. The reaction mechanisms was changed during the CoMoS catalyst deactivation process: triglycerides were deoxygenated into saturated hydrocarbons through HDO pathway over supported CoMoS catalyst with only Lewis acids; however, high temperature operation promoted the transformation of the MoS2 into MoO3, and strong Bronsted acids were produced when MoO3 was deposited on the catalyst support. Although the deoxygenation followed the same reaction pathway, HDO, unsaturated hydrocarbons were produced during triglycerides hydrotreating over MoO3 catalyst. With the existence of Bronsted acids on catalyst, high temperature operation significantly enhanced the coke deposition from unsaturated hydrocarbons. Three causes were observed from the deactivation of the supported CoMo catalyst used in this study: by-product water, loss of sulfur, and coke deposition. The deactivation caused by water and the loss of sulfur was partially recovered through in situ drying and by resulfiding the spent catalyst, and coke deposition was limited by avoiding high temperature operation. coredata.dc:description: The hydrotreating of waste cooking oil (WCO) to produce fuels not only solves waste problem but also recycles energy. CoMoS is regarded as an effective catalyst for the deoxygenation of triglyceride during the hydrotreating process; however, it is easy to deactivate. This article studied the deactivation mechanism of a supported CoMoS commercial catalyst during the hydrotreating of WCO. It was the first time to find triglyceride deoxygenation over different active sites during CoMoS catalyst deactivating process: saturated hydrocarbons were the primary products over MoS2 on the presulfided CoMoS catalyst, and unsaturated hydrocarbons were produced over MoO3 on the spent CoMoS catalyst as the transformation of the MoS2 into MoO3 occurred under high temperature operation. Three causes were observed for the deactivation of the studied catalyst: by-product water, loss of sulfur, and coke deposition. Low temperature operation at 275°C can control the deactivation of CoMoS catalyst due to coke deposition. In-situ drying and resulfiding the spent catalyst were proposed as methods to regenerate the spent catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrotreating of waste cooking oil over supported CoMoS catalyst – Catalyst deactivation mechanism study
